sde.name: SDE
sde.name4: Build your career the right way!!
sde.overview: Before applying for any role, it’s important to understand why you want to do it and what will be required of you for this role. For a software engineering-based role, it’s necessary that you have the desire to build things from scratch, get your hands dirty with new technologies, be enthusiastic to learn new stuff all the time, and be able to apply it to new, impactful interfaces with real-time effects. If this sounds like you, then read on!
sde.readmore:
Your journey begins with a 2-3 week learning phase at the company, focused on mastering key skills like web development and APIs, tailored to your role. During this time, clear communication with your mentor is essential as they guide you through the job’s nuances. While the post-placement period might bring some pressure, the overall atmosphere remains relaxed. As a software engineer, flexible hours are a significant perk, allowing you to work when it suits you best. Typically, you'll spend 7-8 hours a day working, leaving weekends free for personal activities and time with friends.

Daily tasks
  • Code a part of a software application
  • Run tests to ensure the software works as expected
  • Review code from another engineer
  • Work on optimizing the software speed and performance
  • Listen to the client or company to understand what new features they want
  • Stay up to date on software technology and upgrades
sde.branches: No strict preference. Relevant courses (especially in CS, MT, and EE) are crucial. Key courses include COL100, COL106, MTL342, and MTL103
sde.skills:
Hard Skills: Strong foundation in Data Structures and Algorithms (DSA), competitive programming, and knowledge of web development or related fields.
Soft Skills: Effective communication, teamwork, adaptability, and leadership
sde.trajectory: Career stability with many professionals staying 6-20 years in the role. Growth is smooth with promotions in 1-1.5 years. Options for career progression include moving into management or continuing as a senior developer
sde.resume:
CGPA cutoff: Typically 7.5 (some companies may require 8).
Key highlights: Programming assignments, especially from COL100/COL106, participation in hackathons, and self-driven projects in new tech stacks
sde.companies:
Pure SDE Roles: Google, Microsoft, Uber, Amazon, Flipkart, Facebook, Adobe, Infosys, Samsung, LinkedIn, Dell, Intuit.
SDE Roles in Finance: JPMC, Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs.
downwardLabels: First year    Get good hands on !! experience with !! coding in COL100
Second year    Seek coding-related projects with  !! professors; interdisciplinary work is a !! plus
Summer break before 3rd year    Use pre-internship summer to tackle !! hard DSA questions and study OS, !! DBMS, and other theories.
Interview    Interviews focus on DSA; answer !! expected starting from brute force to !! optimal solutions.
upwardLabels: Second year    Regardless of taking COL106, familiarize !! yourself with data structures and !! algorithms in any language you prefer
Second year    Complete intermediate-level DSA !! questions by the end of 4th semester
A month before interviews    Tests begins for different companies after !! CV shortlist (if any) May have some !! aptitude questions

guide.html:
The Complete Guide to SDE Preparation

Guidelines for Preparation

  1. Preferred Language: Consider using C++ as your primary language. Some HFT firms mandate C++ for coding rounds.
  2. Preparation Strategy (Based on Time):
    • More than 3 Months: Start with CP to build intuition and mathematical skills. Gradually shift to DSA-specific preparation closer to your OAs and Interviews.
    • 2-3 Months: Use the above resources but skip dedicated CP prep (though regular contests are still essential).
    • Less than 1-2 Months: Focus on Striver's Leetcode sheet and past company Online Assessments (available on Leetcode discussions).
  3. Important Concepts:
    • Master OOPS concepts since they are asked in nearly all company interviews. (Use GeekforGeeks)
    • (Optional) Learn core CS concepts (OS, Networks, DBMS); some firms ask MCQ-based problems in their OAs regarding these concepts.
  4. Don't Skip DSA, even if you are strong in CP: Companies often ask standard DSA questions in their online assessments and interviews.
  5. Mocks: Practice company-wise mocks on platforms like Maang and others.

DSA Prep

  1. Striver SDE Sheet: Striver's SDE Sheet
  2. Dynamic Programming, Graphs and Binary Search (A2Z Sheet): A2Z Sheet
  3. Neetcode Roadmap: Neetcode Roadmap
  4. Focus especially on Backtracking (it sets the base for DP).
  5. Do Leetcode Daily Problems: Use extensions like Leetrooms to create randomized problem sets.
  6. If time permits, explore InterviewBit problems (interface can be a challenge).

Competitive Programming (CP)

  1. TLE 31 Sheets: TLE 31 Sheets
  2. Participate in regular contests on Codeforces and CodeChef
    • Solve at least Problem C in Div2 and Problem E in Div3.
  3. Optional Advanced CP Resources:
    • Problems in the USACO Guide.
    • CP Algorithms and related problems: CP Algorithms
    • Various ladders such as A2OJ and ACD.
    • Follow YouTube channels like William Lin, Errichto Algorithms, etc.

Treat this Repository as a Bible:

IITD-CSE Internship Season Repository

CSES Must-Do Topics

  1. Sorting and Searching
  2. Dynamic Programming
  3. Graph Algorithms
  4. Range Queries
  5. Tree Algorithms

Approach: Do problems with a solved count of more than 8K (use the CSES helper extension to filter efficiently).

Industry Trivia

  1. Core CS: DE Shaw and some HFT firms focus heavily on core CS and C++ fundamentals.
  2. Inclusivity: Big firms like Amazon and many startups provide equal opportunities to all branches if your CGPA exceeds 7.

Advice and Motivation

  1. Challenges Are Normal:
    • Preparing for a SDE interview can be a challenging and sometimes frustrating journey. There will be days when you feel stuck and see little to no progress. You may find that you struggle to solve certain problems that your friends manage to solve quickly. It’s important to remember that everyone has a different learning pace, and it's perfectly okay to take your time. In an SDE interview, what matters most is your approach and thought process, rather than simply arriving at the correct solution.
  2. Shortlisting Phase:
    • This is the toughest part of the journey. (Sadly) Companies often shortlist candidates based on CGPA, branch, and pre-college achievements (like national Olympiads) etc. Shortlisting results can be unfortunate at times, even after you've performing well in OAs.
    • Remember that many great companies come after Day 1 and Day 2 (e.g., Wells Fargo, Deutsche Bank, JLR, Microsoft, Tech Mahindra etc)
  3. Don't ignore Quant Prep:
    • Even if you are targeting SDE roles, practice Brainsteller puzzles and Puzzledquant problems. Companies like Goldman Sachs and JPMC include these directly in their aptitude rounds or interviews.

Final Note:

The journey is tough, but remember that setbacks are part of the process. Stick to the plan, stay consistent, and trust your preparation. All the best!

Content credits: Pratham Malhotra EE'26

quant.name: Quant
quant.name4: Build your career the right way!!
quant.overview: Before applying for any role, it’s important to understand why you want to do it and what will be required of you for this role. A career in quantitative analysis is all about solving complex puzzles with a mix of mathematical, statistical, and programming skills. If you enjoy tackling challenging problems, analyzing data, and creating your own tools, then a Quant role might be the perfect fit for you.
quant.readmore:
As a Quant, your typical day might involve:
  • Analyzing financial data using mathematical and statistical methods.
  • Developing algorithms and models to predict market trends.
  • Writing custom tools and software to process and clean messy data.
  • Collaborating with team leaders to work on projects that align with the company's strategic goals.
  • Continuously learning and applying new techniques in fields like data analysis, probability, and game theory.
quant.payscale:
Median Joining Package: ₹50-70 LPA
Quants typically receive higher compensation than most other fields, reflecting the high expectations and specialized skills required.
quant.branches: Preferred branches include CS1, CS5, MT1, MT6 (also consider electrical branches). However, a strong foundation in mathematics, probability, and statistics is crucial, regardless of the branch.
quant.skills:
Exceptional coding skills, particularly in C++ and Python.
Proficiency in Object-Oriented Programming, Data Analysis Techniques, and Statistical Methods.
Strong problem-solving abilities, with a deep understanding of probability and game theory.
quant.trajectory:
High-pressure environments with high rewards with potential job switches after a few years or transitions to tech.
Significant pay hikes and complex problem-solving opportunities for those who excel.
Paths include further specialization or shifts to tech/finance roles
quant.resume:
• Strong CGPA or department rank.
  • Projects in coding and quantitative analysis.
  • Competitive programming experience.
  • Hackathons or self-driven projects showcasing problem-solving skills.
quant.companies:
Elite Quant Firms: Tower Research Capital, Optiver, Jane Street, Citadel Securities, Quadeye, Alphagrep, Graviton, NK Securities.
Finance Giants with Quant Roles: JP Morgan Chase, Goldman Sachs.
downwardLabels: Post 3rd Sem    Build your CV, Do projects in areas you like, find an !! internship/project for the summer, !! Participate in tech competitions to build schols
1 month before interviews    Begin company-specific test !! preparation in shortlisted companies
upwardLabels: Throughout the Journey    Maintain a high CGPA and regularly give!! contest on codeforces
Post 4th sem    Follow the resources mentioned for brainteasers, !! probability and programming problems
2 weeks before interviews    HR prep, Mock interviews, !! Market Making

guide.html:
The complete guide for Quant preparation

The Process:

Brush up your probability theory and start solving problems on Brainstellar/Puzzledquant and then move on to the books. Give plenty of time and effort before you look at the hint/solution. Intuition builds over time. You’ll be able to solve more and more problems on your own once you get the hang of it. Give Codeforces contests regularly. Remember, rating doesn’t matter much. Company-specific prep can be done towards the end of the summer (mental math, market making prep etc). Another important aspect which people miss out—HR Round is important. Do some mock interviews with your friends and seniors so you don’t get flustered during the actual interview. Look at some HR questions and prepare your answers well.

Probability Theory:

MTL106 is helpful. You can also refer to Introduction to Probability Models by Sheldon Ross. Topics—Conditional probability, Bayes Theorem etc (JEE Stuff). Random Variables, PDF, CDF, Expected Value, Variance. Some common distributions (discrete and continuous both), Central Limit Theorem.

Puzzles, Probability Questions:

Brainstellar website, Heard on the Street, A Practical Guide to Quantitative Finance Interviews by Xinfeng Zhao, 50 Challenging Problems in Probability. These are the 4 standard, well-known resources (not all chapters are relevant, only probability and brainteasers). I recommend using PuzzledQuant; it helped me keep track and has a good collection of problems (Brainstellar is a subset of PuzzledQuant).

CP:

Competitive Programmer’s Handbook—a go-to guide for some new algorithm you found in an editorial, CP-Algorithms to learn about any new algorithm and its implementation.

C++ Concepts (More Important for Quant Developer Roles):

Learn C++

Mental Math:

Arithmetic Game, Games | PuzzledQuant

ML (Optional):

If interested, you can refer to the following sections from Prof. Parag’s course COL774: Machine Learning
  1. Supervised Learning—Linear Regression, Gradient Descent, Stochastic Gradient Descent
  2. Linear Regression—Alternate interpretation (probabilistic), Logistic Regression, GLMs
  3. Decision Trees, Random Forests

Other resources—Aniruddha-Deb/quant-prep, Quant Interview/Test Prep, Internship Season | Chinmay Mittal

core.name: Core !! (Electrical)
core.name4: Build your career the right way!!
core.overview: If you have a passion for Electrical Engineering (EE) courses and enjoy hands-on circuit and chip design, a Core Electrical profile could be ideal for you. This role involves designing, simulating, and fabricating advanced circuits for various applications, such as digital processors, power electronic converters, and RF/Mixed Signal systems. If you’re excited by creating and optimizing hardware and have a keen interest in cutting-edge technology, read on!
core.readmore:
Your role starts with designing and engineering hardware for specific applications. As you gain experience, tasks become more specialized. Key roles include Analog/RFIC/Mixed Signal Design Engineer, Digital Design Engineer, Physical Design/Verification Engineer, and Powertrain Designer. Software Engineers in this domain work with embedded systems, programming boards, and developing testing platforms. While company cultures vary, they generally offer a supportive environment with manageable stress levels.

Daily tasks
  • Design and optimize circuits for various applications
  • Simulate and test hardware components
  • Work on embedded systems and programming (for Software Engineers)
  • Collaborate with teams on complex projects
core.payscale:
Base Salary: ₹20-50 LPA (varies by role and skills)
Internships: ₹40K-80K per month
core.branches: Primarily EE, but CS, EP (in some companies), and MT students with relevant skills are also considered.
core.skills:
Hard Skills: Circuit Design, Digital Electronics, Programming.
Key courses include Digital Electronics, Circuit Theory, Control Systems, and Analog Electronic Circuits
core.trajectory:
Career growth starts gradually but becomes highly rewarding with experience. Engineers often advance to lead roles within 8-10 years.
The expanding semiconductor industry in India offers stable and lucrative long-term career opportunities.
core.resume:
• Relevant EE projects and internships (research or corporate)
  • CGPA of 7-7.5+ is generally sufficient; some companies may require 8+.
  • Strong technical knowledge and relevant projects are prioritized over extracurricular activities.
core.companies: Nvidia, Texas Instruments, Qualcomm, Intel, Jaguar, Land Rover, MediaTek, Cadence
downwardLabels: Post 4th Sem    Corporate or research intern, !! preferably in the manufacturing !! sector

Prior to Day 1    Revisit your journey from childhood to IIT, your !! hobbies and any life changing events (these get !! asked a lot in interviews). Also revisit !! coursework and attempt mock aptitude tests
upwardLabels: Prior to 4th Sem    Boost CG as much as possible !! !!
4th Sem    Take up project work either included !! in course, or led by a professor

guide.html:
The complete guide for Core Preparation

The Process:

The selection process for an FMCG internship typically involves three to four rounds:
  1. Application Stage: Fill out a form detailing your internships, academic achievements, and skills. Highlight relevant experiences and ensure your details are precise since this forms the company’s first impression of you. Some companies also include a psychometric test to assess personality traits and cultural fit. Treat this test as a chance to showcase your authenticity—don’t overthink your answers.
  2. Group Discussion (GD): Emphasis on quality over quantity. Focus on contributing meaningfully to the discussion rather than dominating it. Structure your thoughts before speaking and encourage quieter members to participate. This demonstrates teamwork and improves the overall discussion quality.
  3. Interview Stage:
    • Technical Round: This assesses your understanding of key concepts and the projects listed on your resume. Be clear and concise in your answers and prepare for follow-up questions.
    • HR Round: This evaluates your fit for the company and role. Expect questions about your strengths, weaknesses, and past experiences.
    Throughout the process, be confident, know your CV thoroughly, and stay calm under pressure.

Building an Effective CV:

Your CV is a crucial part of the application process. Here’s how your CV shapes up -
  • Academic Background: Include your 10th and 12th-grade marks, competitive exam achievements (e.g., NTSE, KVPY, JEE ranks), and relevant certifications.
  • CGPA: Most FMCG companies require a CGPA of 7-7.5. Companies like Wipro prefer 8+. A strong CGPA enhances your CV, but exceptional internships and projects can compensate for a lower score.
  • Internships: Prefer industry-relevant internships such as those in manufacturing roles. SURA projects or AI/ML internships can make your profile stand out.
  • Projects: Include diverse and impactful projects such as COL Projects or Department projects to showcase versatility.
  • PORs and ECAs: Emphasize positions of responsibility and continued involvement in clubs/activities to reflect growth and commitment.
  • Relevant Courses: List courses aligned with the FMCG industry.

Building your profile during 3rd and 4th Semesters:

Approach professors for research projects. Complete internships in relevant areas to gain practical experience and do AI/ML projects to differentiate yourselves among applicants. At the same time, strengthen your understanding of core concepts relevant to the FMCG domain, such as supply chain operations or data analytics. This balance of practical experience and strong fundamentals will give you an edge in the selection process.

Interview Tips:

Technical Round: Be concise and prepared to explain your listed projects and internships in detail. If a question seems unclear, ask for clarification and steer the conversation toward your strengths. Be prepared to explain every point and link it to the role you’re applying for. HR Round: Create a brief but compelling self-introduction. Highlight academic interests, leadership roles, and experiences, connecting them to the company’s vision and the role you’re applying for. Stay calm and ask insightful questions about the role or company. Confidence and calmness can make a significant difference, especially when dealing with challenging questions.

finance.name: Analytics
finance.name4: Build your career the right way!!
finance.overview: A career in finance involves managing and analyzing financial data, making strategic decisions, and helping businesses achieve their financial goals. Whether you're interested in investment banking, private equity, or finance within a tech company, understanding the demands and rewards of the field is crucial. If you’re ready for a challenging yet rewarding career with diverse opportunities, finance might be the right fit for you!
finance.readmore:
In finance, daily activities vary based on the specific role. In investment banking, expect long hours (80-100 per week) dealing with high-stakes deals and rigorous analyses. Private equity roles involve around 80 hours a week, with more intensive periods during active deals. Finance roles in tech companies generally offer a better work-life balance, with 40-50 hours a week. The day involves reviewing financial reports, conducting market analysis, and preparing presentations for stakeholders. The role demands strong analytical skills, attention to detail, and adaptability to fast-paced environments.

Daily Tasks
  • Analyze financial data and create financial models
  • Prepare and present reports to senior management
  • Monitor market trends and financial performance
  • Collaborate with other departments and clients
finance.payscale: Joining PayScale: ₹10-30 LPA (varies by role and company)
finance.branches: No specific branch preference; relevant coursework and experience are more important.
finance.skills:
Hard Skills: Strong analytical and quantitative skills, and knowledge of programming languages.
Soft Skills: Analytical thinking and effective communication
finance.trajectory: The finance sector in India is growing, with increasing economic activity and foreign investments. Career prospects are strong, with opportunities for advancement into senior roles or specializations in areas like investment banking or private equity.
finance.resume:
• Strong CGPA
  • Finance-related projects and coursework
  • Relevant internships or work experience
finance.companies: Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, American Express, NK Securities, J.P. Morgan Chase, Barclays, DMI Finance, Alphagrep Securities, Piramal, Quadria
upwardLabels: Start by identifying the !! exact profile of analytics you !! want to target !! e.g Finance, Data etc
4th Sem    Develop niche knowledge about !! SQL and DBMS in totality
Post 4th Sem    Learn from your projects and !! practice the resources given in the !! written guide
downwardLabels: 3rd Sem    Start coding and reach an optimum !! level till your winter break
Continue with project lookouts and  !! gather the projects as mentioned in !! the written guide

guide.html:
The complete guide for Analytics preparation

Selection Procedure:

The selection procedure for such profiles usually consists of three main stages: Tests, CV shortlisting, and Interviews. Although for some companies, you may have to submit an assignment or decks as well! Clearing the test is the primary hurdle for you to finally crack the intern.

Test Preparation:

The test preparation usually must be multi-faceted. You must have a good amount of knowledge of database and management systems. If you are really eyeing for a good edge over your peers, have sufficient coding experience and theoretical knowledge of SQL, and priority scheduling. For cracking good interns at this level, you might be asked to code in the tests, usually leveling up to div2- Problem B on CF is sufficient. To further polish your candidature, learn basic ML concepts such as regression, Neural Networks, Activation Functions, etc. These may comprise a set of questions in your test.

CV Preparation:

The most vital part of your CV is your CG and your projects. An analytics CV is like a jack of all trade CV. You must list down your projects that are relevant for the analyst role, such as projects involving Big Data Handling, rigorous machine learning applications, and stuff like VBA and SQL. Make sure to add the technical skills section and list down the programming languages you know, including Python and SQL. If you have time, getting a nudge of R programming will definitely boost your candidature due to its formidable visualization and processing capability. If you don’t have projects, do them on your own and learn the basic intricacies they consist of. If you are at the right place, apply for SURA, which includes the above-mentioned requirements.

PORs:

Do list down your PORs in a nice fashion, especially those that highlight your people skills.

Interviews:

Your interview may consist of questions that test your analytical and mathematical skills. Go through Brainstellar puzzles at least twice and practice as many puzzles as you can.

Resources:

GeeksforGeeks DBMS Scheduling, YouTube Video, PuzzledQuant, Google Drive, Brainstellar

ai-ml.name: AI/ML
ai-ml.name4: Build your career the right way!!
ai-ml.overview: Ever wondered how modern technologies work? At the heart of many innovations are Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML), enabling systems to learn from data, make decisions, and solve complex problems. These technologies impact nearly every aspect of life—voice assistants, personalized recommendations, weather predictions, and more. In healthcare, they aid early diagnosis and personalized treatments. In finance, they detect fraud and optimize investments. Industries like agriculture and robotics benefit from AI and ML through automation and increased efficiency. At their core, AI and ML rely on mathematical principles and advanced algorithms, using tools like TensorFlow and PyTorch to analyze data and make predictions. By combining theoretical knowledge with practical applications, these technologies empower us to develop intelligent systems that solve real-world challenges, transforming how we live and work.
ai-ml.readmore:
Daily Tasks
AI/ML careers are broadly split into research and development roles, each requiring mathematical and programming expertise but differing in focus.

Research roles
Involve developing new algorithms, exploring theoretical foundations, and tackling advanced topics like generative AI and explainable AI. These roles are found in academia, research labs, and innovative companies.

Development roles
Focus on building and deploying machine learning models to address real-world problems. These practical roles are prevalent in industries like finance, healthcare, and e-commerce, driving impactful solutions through applied AI/ML techniques.
ai-ml.payscale: Median Joining Package: Data varies; typically high in leading tech companies and research institutions.
ai-ml.branches:
Research Roles:
Circuital branches like CSE, EE, and MT are preferred due to their strong theoretical foundation.
Development Roles:
Open to all branches, as practical applications value problem-solving and programming skills
ai-ml.skills:
Research Roles:
  • Linear Algebra, Probability Theory, Multivariable Calculus, Optimization
  • Programming (Python, R, and research tools like Jupyter Notebooks and PyTorch)
  • Domain Expertise (LLMs), generative models, and neural networks).
Development Roles:
  • Python (TensorFlow, Scikit-learn, PyTorch, Jupyter)
  • Tools like Docker, Kubernetes, and cloud platforms (AWS, GCP, Azure)
  • Solid understanding of applied statistics and probability.
ai-ml.trajectory:
Research:
  • Pursue advanced studies (Master’s/Ph.D.), publish in top-tier conferences, and work in leading research labs (Google Brain, DeepMind, FAIR).
  • Transition to academic roles or apply research in AI startups.
Development:
  • Master AI/ML tools contribute to open-source projects and progress to leadership roles (tech lead, manager, or product manager).
  • Offer AI/ML consulting or freelancing across industries.
ai-ml.resume:
Research:
  • High CGPA and department ranks.
  • Published research papers in reputed AI/ML conferences or journals.
  • Internships at research labs or innovative tech companies.
Development:
  • Successful machine learning projects with measurable impact.
  • Practical experience with data pipelines and model deployment.
  • Collaborative projects demonstrating teamwork and initiative.
ai-ml.companies:
(not necessarily on-campus recruitments)
Research:
  • Research Labs: Microsoft Research, FAIR (Meta), Adobe Research.
  • Universities: MIT, Stanford, IITs, CMU
  • Companies: OpenAI, DeepMind, Anthropic, Meta.
Development:
  • Companies: Microsoft AI, Amazon AI, NVIDIA.
  • Startups: Glean, Eightfold AI, Cohere, Stability AI,
  • Domains: Healthcare (Zebra Medical), Finance (American Express)

Probability Theory:

MTLI06 is helpful. You can also refer to Introduction to Probability Models.

consult.name: Consult
consult.name4: Build your career the right way!!
consult.overview: If you’re interested in solving complex business problems, working with diverse teams, and influencing organizational decisions, a career in consulting might be the right path for you. Consulting involves advising companies on a variety of issues, from strategy and operations to finance and technology.
consult.readmore:
Your journey typically begins with rigorous training in core consulting skills, such as problem structuring, data analysis, and client management. You'll quickly get involved in client-facing projects, where you’ll apply your skills to solve real business challenges.
Do talk to your seniors in this area before deciding upon consulting to learn the pros and the cons of the profile. For instance, it’s known for a heavy workload and an often difficult work-life balance but offers an exceptional career growth potential.

Daily Tasks
  • Analyzing data to identify trends and insights (Working on a lot of excel sheets and powerpoints)
  • Developing strategies and recommendations based on market research and analysis.
  • Preparing and delivering presentations to clients.
  • Working closely with client teams to implement solutions.
consult.payscale:
Average Internship Stipend: ₹1 Lakh
Base Salary: ₹20-25 LPA
Tend to pay lesser than other profiles initially but offer a very steep salary increase
consult.branches: No specific branch preference. DR’s of any branch are preferred, CG matters
consult.skills:
Soft Skills - Management skills, Communication skills, Leadership skills, Problem Solving
Hard Skills - Excel, Teams, Data Analysis, Presentation Tools, Project Management
consult.trajectory:
A career in consulting offers a structured yet dynamic growth path, typically starting with entry-level roles like Analyst or Associate Consultant. With experience and strong performance, you can expect promotions every 1-2 years in the early stages, advancing through roles such as Consultant, Senior Consultant, and Manager.
Most consultants opt out of consulting in a few years. There are a lot of exit options - startups, private equity, management roles, MBAs etc
consult.resume:
There is a CV shortlisting in consulting roles which is a huge bottleneck as students apply. 20-30 shortlists are made (might vary with company) who would be eligible for further rounds. Hence making a good CV is very important.
A consulting CV has 5 sections
  • CG
  • Scholastic Achievememts
  • Internship (Startup/Research/Corporate)
  • POR
  • ECA
When a section of your CV is above average, its known as a ‘spike’. Generally, you should be shortlisted if you have at least 3-4 ‘spikes’ among the 5 sections.
We advise you to have a talk with your seniors or see the BSW Podcasts to understand the CV Building procedure in detail.
consult.companies: McKinsey & Company, Boston Consulting Group (BCG), Bain & Company, LEK Consulting, Strategy&, Kearney, Accenture, Nomura, KPMG
downwardLabels: Post 3rd Sem    Complete internship/project to boost CV. !! Start reaching out for one timely
1-2 months before interviews    Form case group and start !! practicing cases
upwardLabels: Start shaping your CV convey !! the story you want! !! Look to achieve ‘spikes’.
Post 4th Sem    Completcorporate/startup/ !! foreign internships. !! Start reaching out during 4th Sem
Shortly after shortlists    Buddies are assigned; !! buddy cases begin

guide.html:
The complete guide for Consult preparation

Process Overview:

The selection process for consulting internships consists of three main stages: CV Shortlisting, Buddy Rounds, and Offline Interviews. CV shortlisting is by far the biggest bottleneck, where ~50 unique students are shortlisted from a pool of 500+ applicants. As such, preparing a standout CV is crucial. Begin working on your CV early to allow sufficient time for refinement and development. Your CV should tell a compelling story about your achievements and experiences.

Building Your CV:

A consulting CV typically comprises five sections: CG, Scholastic Achievements, Internships, PORs, and ECAs. A consulting CV is judged via the ‘spike’ framework. A ‘spike’ section is one where you’re well above the average applicant. It is the section that stands out to the person evaluating your CV. Although there is some subjectivity to what you call a spike, being well above average in atleast 3-4 sections is non-negotiable for a shortlist among the top firms.

CG:

  • Generally top firms consider CG above 8 to be satisfactory, some firms have also put hard barriers in the past. A CG above 8.5 or 9 is an ideal spike.
  • A lower CG makes getting shortlisted tougher but can be compensated by excelling in other sections. (Note: These numbers are subject to the relative performance of the applicants in a particular batch)

Schols:

  • This section includes institute-level awards such as Merit List, Department Rank, and pre-institute achievements like Olympiad ranks or scholarships.
  • If this section of yours is lacking, don’t worry, with some conscious effort you can build your section up to a satisfactory level.

Internships:

  • These include corporate, start-up and research interns (offline/online). It is highly advised to complete multiple internships. Internships in big brand corporations or business schools are valued.
  • An offline intern at a well-established corporate (even more impactful if it is in the consulting sector) or at a foreign research institute are considered as particularly great options. These can be coupled with a remote intern at a business school, which is usually a significantly less time commitment.

PORs:

  • This section conveys the story of your campus involvements over the course of two years. Continuity in POR’s is hence valued, indicating progress in whatever activity you’ve devoted time to.
  • 3rd year POR’s are important. Elected POR’s are generally considered more valuable than nominated POR’s.

ECAs:

  • Organize your ECAs into 2-3 broad sections to provide structure. Having multiple ECA’s in a few select sections shows excellence and dedication as opposed to having them scattered across various sections.
  • Ensure that the most valuable achievements are presented well to make your CV stand out.

Buddy Rounds:

Once you are shortlisted, the firm will allot you buddies. A buddy is a consultant working at the firm and is usually an alum of the institute. Buddies will conduct case solving sessions with you, guiding you through your preparation. These sessions are evaluative, with firms using them to create a “hotlist” of preferred candidates. Although not being on the hotlist does not eliminate your chances, performing well in these rounds increases your likelihood of being prioritized.

Case Prep:

  • Form a Case Group: Work with 3-4 serious aspirants who have diverse networks. This allows you to access varied insights and resources. Case groups help maintain regular practice but also seek opportunities to practice with seniors and peers outside your group.
  • You can start practicing cases 1-2 months before your interviews ensuring you’re at your peak during the interviews and senior buddy cases. Start with guesstimates and profitability, while aiming to cover other types of cases towards the end of your prep.
  • Practice in pairs, taking turns as interviewer and interviewee. After each case, spend time analyzing your performance and building a deeper understanding of frameworks and solutions.

Resources:

  • A conventionally followed method to begin is getting an overview of case preps via the recorded lectures of Victor Cheng and Case Interviews Cracked: YouTube Playlist (stick to the first few relevant lectures)
  • Case Compendium (a good beginner-friendly option), Case Interviews Cracked and IIM Ahmedabad Case Book (slightly more advanced than the former) are some conventional case books used by applicants. Download here

Basic Introduction

What is the Common Admission Test?

The Common Admission Test is a national-level entrance examination conducted annually by the Indian Institutes of Management. It serves as the primary admission test for MBA/PGDM programs at the Indian Institutes of Management and is also accepted by over 1,200 other top business schools across India.

Who Should Apply?

  • Students in the final year of their undergraduate studies
  • Graduates looking to pursue an MBA/PGDM
  • Working professionals aiming to transition into managerial roles or gain leadership skills
  • Individuals planning a career switch or interested in entrepreneurship

Eligibility Criteria

  • A Bachelor’s degree with a minimum of 50% marks or equivalent CGPA (45% for Scheduled Caste/Scheduled Tribe/Persons with Disabilities)
  • Final-year undergraduate students are also eligible to apply
  • No age limit
  • No restriction on the number of attempts (the exam is conducted once per year)

What Is a Good Score?

  • 99.7+ percentile: Typically required for top Indian Institutes of Management (Ahmedabad, Bangalore, Calcutta)
  • 97–99 percentile: Competitive for institutes like Indian Institute of Management Lucknow, Indian Institute of Technology Bombay (Shailesh J. Mehta School of Management), Management Development Institute, S. P. Jain Institute of Management and Research, etc.
  • 90–97 percentile: Eligible for newer Indian Institutes of Management and several Tier‑1 private business schools

Self‑Study vs Coaching

Self‑Study: Plenty of quality resources are available online (videos, PDFs, past papers).
Coaching Institutes: Offer structured programs with mocks, classes, and doubt resolution (for example, iQuanta, TIME, IMS, Career Launcher).
Note: Coaching is optional and can help streamline your preparation.

What Happens After the Exam?

  • Shortlisting by business schools is based on Common Admission Test percentile, academic background, work experience, and diversity factors.
  • Further rounds typically include: Written Ability Test / Analytical Writing Test and Personal Interview.
  • Final selection is based on a composite score considering all these components.

Validity & Attempts

  • Score validity: 1 year
  • Attempts: Unlimited over the years (once per year)
  • Age limit: None

Alternatives to the Common Admission Test

If the Common Admission Test does not go well, consider these entrance exams: XAT (by XLRI), SNAP (by Symbiosis), NMAT (by GMAC), CMAT (by NTA), MAT. Some private colleges offer direct admissions based on academic profile.

Should Engineers Consider the Common Admission Test?

Absolutely. A large portion of Common Admission Test aspirants and top scorers each year come from engineering backgrounds due to their quantitative aptitude. Engineers are eligible even without prior work experience, and many write the exam in their final year of college while preparing for placements.

Pattern

  • Exam duration: 2 hours (120 minutes).
  • Two types of questions:
    • Multiple Choice Questions (correct: +3; incorrect: −1)
    • Type In The Answer (no options; no negative marking)
  • Three sections (each section has a dedicated 40‑minute timer and appears in fixed order):
    • Verbal Ability and Reading Comprehension
    • Data Interpretation and Logical Reasoning
    • Quantitative Aptitude
  • Number of questions varies across the three sections and by year.

Note on Syllabus

There is no official syllabus released. Preparation is based on past‑year patterns and representative topic lists.

Verbal Ability and Reading Comprehension — Preparation

Data Interpretation and Logical Reasoning — Preparation

Quantitative Aptitude — Preparation

Mocks and Planning

When to start

Do topic drills and sectionals early; begin regular full‑length mocks from August/September.

How many

Quality over quantity: ~10–20 full mocks plus focused sectionals is common.

Mock analysis (non‑negotiable)

  • Tag every error as concept / misread / speed / guess.
  • Redo unsolved questions; turn learnings into brief checklists (e.g., “draw a table,” “check units,” “scan all sets first”).
  • Track topic‑wise accuracy weekly.

Simple weekly loop

  • Mon–Fri: 60–90 min Quantitative Aptitude + 45 min reading/paraphrasing + 45–60 min Data Interpretation/Logical Reasoning sets
  • Sat: 1 full mock + 2 hours analysis
  • Sun: Weak‑area clinic + revise formulas/ratios/shortcuts

Indian Institute of Management Ahmedabad Selection Criteria — Explained

1) Minimum Common Admission Test Percentile Requirement (Preliminary Screening)

  • For the General category: Overall percentile ≥ 80; Each section ≥ 70 percentile. If these are not met, the profile is not considered.

2) Application Rating Score (≈35% weightage in shortlisting)

  • Class 10 marks: Points by percentage band (e.g., ≥90% = 10 points; 81–90% = 8 points). Note: Based on all subjects listed on the mark sheet, not the best four or five.
  • Class 12 marks: Points depend on stream (Science, Commerce, Arts); Commerce/Arts bands are slightly more lenient than Science.
  • Graduation marks: Mapped to an Academic Category (AC1: Medical; AC2: Professional—CA/CS/CFA/ICWA; AC3: Commerce/Management/Economics; AC4: Engineering; AC5: Arts & Humanities; AC6: Other).
  • Work experience (maximum 5 points):
    • Less than 12 months: 0 points
    • 13 to 36 months: (months − 11) × 0.2
    • More than 36 months: capped at 5 points
  • Shortlisting composite score: 0.35 × Application Rating + 0.65 × Common Admission Test percentile

Why some candidates get calls at lower percentiles (e.g., ~87)

Shortlisting is done category‑wise, with a cap on interview calls for each Academic Category in the General category: AC1, AC2, AC3, and AC5 up to 100 candidates each; AC4 (Engineers) up to 150 candidates. Engineers face the densest competition and usually need very high percentiles (often 99.7+), while under‑represented categories may get calls at lower percentiles.

Final Selection Criteria (Post‑Interview Round)

Final score: 0.25 × Common Admission Test score + 0.15 × Application Rating + 0.10 × Analytical Writing Test + 0.50 × Personal Interview

  • Weight on the Common Admission Test reduces from 65% (shortlisting stage) to 25%.
  • 60% of weight lies on the interview day (Analytical Writing Test + Personal Interview).
  • No category caps in final selection; performance on the day is decisive.

Syllabus (Reference PDF)

Important: The syllabus is not officially released. The PDF below is reference‑only, based on past‑year patterns, and should not be trusted completely.

Senior Advice

Display these as clickable cards.

Vagish (100 percentile)
  • No new concepts beyond Joint Entrance Examination level—focus on speed and accuracy.
  • 2 to 4–5 months of consistent preparation is sufficient (you do not need a year‑long grind).
  • Primary focus: Last 3 years’ previous year questions and selected mock tests.
  • Daily time: Even 15–30 minutes/day over a long stretch is effective; quality and consistency matter more than hours.
  • Mocks attempted: Around 10.
  • Explore: Entrepreneurship; What after MBA; Financial knowledge; Current affairs / Static General Knowledge; Indian and foreign context; Finance involved; Case competitions.
Laksh (100 percentile)
  • Be strong in at least two sections to insure the overall percentile even if one section dips.
  • Solve as many mock tests as possible, especially in the last few days, to handle varying section difficulty.
  • Speed is key for a 100 percentile—aim to attempt almost all questions with ~90% accuracy.
  • Mental calculations: Train with mental‑math resources (e.g., QuantGuide).
  • Interview experience: Ahmedabad focused slightly on undergrad course content; Bangalore and Calcutta felt more general‑knowledge‑based (panel dependent).

Quick Do/Don’t

Do

  • Read daily and paraphrase each paragraph (VARC).
  • Scan all sets first and pick clean ones (DILR).
  • Maintain a mistake log and review weekly.
  • Drill arithmetic shortcuts, approximation, and fraction–percentage pairs (QA).
  • Spend more time analyzing mocks than taking new ones.

Don’t

  • Memorize vocabulary lists—learn words in context.
  • Stay stuck on one DILR set beyond 13–14 minutes.
  • Neglect TITA questions—there is no negative marking.
  • Over‑engineer simple quantitative questions.

Disclaimer: This guide is informational and based on recent exam trends and senior insights. The official CAT authority (IIMs) may change pattern/criteria without prior notice. Always refer to the official CAT website and institute‑specific admissions pages for the latest updates.

The Complete Guide to Higher Studies

When Should You Start?


Ideally, start 4 months before the application deadlines. This timeline gives you ample time to:
  • Prepare a list of target universities.
  • Request 3 Letters of Recommendation (LORs).
  • Take exams like GRE/TOEFL/IELTS (if required).
  • Draft and review your Statement of Purpose (SOP) and resume.
  • Address any application-specific questions.

Typical Application Timeline

  • By December: Finalize your SOP, resume, and LORs.
  • January-February: Submit applications.
  • March-April: Wait for admission results.

Exams Needed

  • GRE: Post-COVID, many universities have waived GRE requirements.
  • TOEFL/IELTS: Proof of English proficiency is usually mandatory unless waived.
  • Some universities might have specific criteria.

How to Select Universities?

Shortlist universities in 3 categories:
  • Dream: High-ranking universities with tough competition.
  • Medium: Universities where you have a fair chance.
  • Safe: Universities with a high probability of admission.

  • Start with a list of 20–40 universities in an Excel sheet and narrow it down to 7–12.
  • Use filters: rankings, research areas, location, funding, and faculty alignment with your interests.

Building a Strong Application

  1. Statement of Purpose (SOP):
    • It is never too late to think about pursuing higher education post-graduation. If you have realized that you want to go for it, then in high probability, you have already answered the “Why?” part to justify that decision to yourself. Now it is time to frame the same thing to justify it to the selectors at universities. The medium to do that is your SOP.
    • Use the SOP to tell your story and explain your motivation for pursuing higher studies.
    • Format suggestions:
      • Your Story (1.25 pages): Highlight relevant academic and professional experiences.
      • Why This University (0.6 pages): Mention how its programs align with your goals.
      • Future Plans (0.15 pages): Briefly outline your aspirations.
  2. Resume:
    • Highlight projects, internships, publications, club activities, and TA/RA experiences relevant to your chosen field.
  3. LORs:
    • Reach out to professors, mentors, or supervisors who know your work well.
    • Give them sufficient time (at least 2–3 weeks) to draft strong recommendations.

Funding Opportunities

  • Teaching Assistantships (TA) and Research Assistantships (RA) are common funding sources.
  • The availability of funding varies by university, so research thoroughly.
  • Highlight your teaching or research experience in your application to increase your chances.

What To Do in Summers: A Guide for Incoming 2nd Year Students

So, the first year is done. You survived the 8 a.m. classes, quizzes out of nowhere, and the limitless all-nighters.

Now it's summer – finally a breather! But before you start binge-watching series, here's a guide to make your summer productive and fun.

1. Explore Career Paths

  • Tech (software/dev/ML/quant)
  • Core (your department stuff)
  • Consulting
  • Finance
  • Research
  • Product
  • The opportunity is limitless.
Try different things and see what sticks— you still have tons of time to explore, don't worry.

2. Start Figuring Out What You Like

  • This is the time to explore what field excites you (tech? consulting? core? something random but cool?)
  • Use the process of elimination – you don’t have to know what you love, but start ruling out what you don’t.
  • You’re usually good at things you’re naturally drawn to – follow that instinct 🧠.
  • Try these out!:
    • Case comps on Unstop – great for exploring consulting.
    • Hackathons on Devfolio or Unstop.
    • CP contests on Codeforces, AtCoder.
    • Check this simulator out and better understand if the profile interests you!
    • See what excites you!!

3. Build Your LinkedIn Profile

This will help at every stage ahead. Refer this guide.

4. Tech Stuff

DSA (COL106)

  • Tough CS course in 2nd year – if you plan to take it, summer prep is a lifesaver.
  • It is one of the best courses to take for non-circuital branches to learn what this technical college is about, tech. It opens up a very viable and great career path.
  • If you struggled with COL100, start by clearing the basics of a programming language. You can go for C++ (recommended), Python or Java.
  • Focus on learning the basic syntax like data types, loops, functions, arrays, etc.
  • After that, start learning DSA (which is the core of COL106).
  • Start with Striver's A2Z DSA Sheet or CodeWithHarry.
  • Practice regularly on LeetCode and Codeforces – this is the MOST IMPORTANT part! Start with 800 level problems on CodeForces and you can change the level of problems accordingly.
  • - Start giving contests from day 1 itself, VERY IMPORTANT!!! You can easily give div 3 and even div 2 contests. (Initially, you’ll face difficulty, but as you learn more, it will get much more comfortable.) Definitely join the cost by devclub, the details of that will be shared very soon.

Machine Learning (ML)

  • If ‘AI or Machine Learning’ sounds exciting, start now. This is the perfect time.
  • Later semesters get hectic (thanks DSA), so this is your chance.
  • Basics: Python + sklearn + YouTube + free courses Here is a list of a few resources, we recommend:
    • Andrew NG (Machine Learning Specialization) is free and a great course
    • Stanford CS229: Machine Learning Full Course taught by Andrew Ng | Autumn 2018 - YouTube
    • StatQuest Youtube Channel (You can learn several ML concepts here)
    • Kaggle: Explore youtube to learn building ML projects on aggle and try them hands-on
      • Remember: It’s not about what you start, but what you complete in the summers, which sets you apart. So if you decide to watch any playlist, complete it.

5. Consulting Curious?

  • If you enjoy problem-solving, structured thinking, or people management – this might be for you! Or you just hate core and tech :(
  • Consulting involves advising companies on a variety of issues, from strategy and operations to finance and technology.
  • Start with case comps - great learning opportunity and just fun!:
    • Unstop: Connecting talent, colleges, & recruiters!
    • IIMs
    • Clubs like BnC, Enactus and energy society have comps during Rendezvous and later Tech GC
      • Try to find like-minded individuals and give Case-comps together. It’s always better when you have someone equally enthusiastic to push you.
  • Explore case studies:
    • Global Business in Practice
    • Wharton: Business Strategy
    • IIMBx: Strategic Management
    • Management Consulting Specialisation
    • University of London: Corporate Strategy
    • Wharton Business Foundation
    • Wharton Business Analytics
  • Communication and storytelling matter here – clubs like DebSoc can help

6. For the Quant Curious

  • Like logic, math, or probability? Check out Brainstellar Brilliant.org, or puzzle platforms – they’re fun and secretly train you for quant, analytics, or finance roles
    • Competitive programming is a must – it’s not just useful for tech roles, but also builds strong problem-solving skills that are valued in quant and trading firms.
  • Platforms like Codeforces, AtCoder, and USACO are great for developing deep problem-solving abilities.
  • These skills are especially useful if you’re aiming for quantitative roles or trading firms in the future.

7. Projects with Professors (aka Research 101)

  • Email professors and ask if they have any summer projects, personalized mails will be better. Show them your eagerness and willingness to work and through persistence you may get the opportunity to work with some professor.
  • Even a little work under the guidance of a professor is highly valued and additionally makes your CV look great too.
  • You’re in IIT Delhi – use it!

8. Talk to Seniors – Seriously

  • Not just +1 seniors, reach out to +2, +3 and alumni too
  • Use LinkedIn, society meets, or randomly text people 😅
  • Ask about real work life, internships, placements, goals, and regrets

Plan Your 2nd Year

Set Clear Goals for Yourself

  • As you head into second year, it’s a good idea to think about what you’d like to explore or achieve — whether it’s applying for a research internship, preparing for a student exchange, or aiming for something like Google Summer of Code.
  • Try breaking that bigger goal into smaller steps. For example:
    • If you want to apply for a foreign intern, you might want to start exploring research areas and building your resume over the next few months.
    • If you’re interested in GSoC, maybe start learning how open-source works and contribute to small projects.
    • Planning for student exchange? Look up the requirements and see where you stand — and what areas you might need to focus on.
  • Everyone’s pace is different — the idea is just to be a bit intentional and aware of what you’re aiming for, so you can work towards it over time.

Refer the compiled report of the FAQs from last year's 'Foreign Intern Session’.

You don’t need to map out your entire year right now. But having even a rough idea of your interests and how to approach them makes everything less stressful. It helps you make the most of opportunities when they do come your way.

Understand the Tradeoffs

  • What’s tech life like? Consulting? Core?
  • How risky/safe is it? Are exits easy?
  • Linear vs exponential growth?
  • 9–5 job or flexible work or full grind?
There’s no right answer – it’s about what YOU prefer. Just be aware of your options. This is the time for you to explore.

Make the Most of IIT Delhi

  • People don’t just come here for the brand – IITD gives you shorter, clearer paths to big goals
  • Opportunities are everywhere – profs, clubs, competitions, alumni, resources
You've already made it here. Don't waste it – use everything that IITD offers.

TL;DR Summer To-Do List

  • Check out https://bswcareerportal.iitd.ac.in/
  • Explore career paths and figure out your interests
  • Start COL106 prep if you’re planning to take it
  • Pick one area (DSA, ML, Quant, etc.) to begin exploring/li>
  • Try a mini-project or a comp
  • Talk to seniors
  • Build your LinkedIn profile
📢 This is a time you will cherish — have fun, don't leave room for regrets.

All in all, this is probably your last “free” summer; use it wisely, but remember to have fun, don’t stress yourself out; your upcoming acads got you covered for that ;)

This is the best time to learn the hobbies you’ve always procrastinated on, learn to drive, pick up that guitar sitting in the corner of your house, use that phone for clicking some aesthetic pics rather than doom-scrolling. Hope you all have a fantastic summer and excited to have you back on campus with your juniors!
